5. Require weekly testing for health care workers, nursing home and assisted living facility employees, even if they do not exhibit symptoms. Nursing homes have been especially vulnerable to COVID-19—testing residents and health care workers once is insufficient.

4. Urgently prioritize contact tracing. As cases rise, it’s critical that health experts trace transmission. Arizona is falling short, and it puts lives at risk. We must follow CDC advice to scale up and train a large workforce of contact tracers to track and stop COVID-19.

3. Expand testing and speed up results. It’s imperative to test more people, and tests need to be available to Arizonans regardless of present symptoms. Result turn-around needs to increase. Delayed test results are a lagging indicator for the seriousness of Arizona's situation.

2. Provide meaningful guidance for small businesses as they re-open. Arizona should follow the lead of states such as Colorado, which helps employers with detailed, actionable guidelines, including how to conduct symptom screenings to keep employees and customers safe.
1. Mandate masks in public places and businesses where physical distancing isn’t possible. Businesses should also be required to provide their employees with masks to wear while working.

This is especially important to reflect on in the wake of anti-racism protests around the country. This is a moment to recognize the discrimination and violence black members of the LGBTQ community face in particular.
This year, especially, we must recognize that the progress the LGBTQ community has made did not come easily -- and that protesting was an effective tactic that advanced the cause for equality.

It still hits me in the gut when I think about it. I know my mom would be thrilled with the progress our country has made. But that she’d also be telling me to “get on it,” and continue pushing. The work is still far from over.

My mom did not live to see the day when gay marriage became legal in Michigan. She passed away in 2011, and it pained me to watch her partner of six years, Annie, care for her in those long ten months, knowing the state would never fully recognize their commitment to each other.

#PrideMonth always makes me think about my mom. She came out in the 1980’s in metro Detroit, long before it was a commonplace thing to do, and lived the rest of her life as a gay woman. http://pbs.twimg.com/ext_tw_video_thumb/1272312597551951872/pu/img/KU9FWXezUPflJPoK.jpg https://video.twimg.com/ext_tw_video/1272312597551951872/pu/vid/480x270/MR8WOGBd9q_4TmR-.mp4?tag=10
